Key to the genera of Poaceae

source.author: Walsh, N.G.
source.title: Poaceae
source.in_title: Flora of Victoria. Vol. 2. Ferns and Allied Plants, Conifers and Monocotyledons
source.citation: From: Walsh, N.G. (1994). Poaceae. In: Walsh, N.G.; Entwisle, T.J. (eds), Flora of Victoria. Vol. 2. Ferns and Allied Plants, Conifers and Monocotyledons. Inkata Press, Melbourne.

leads.lead_text: Inflorescence of 1 to several spikes; rigid, strongly rhizomatous, usually semi-aquatic grasses of tidal mud-flats
Inflorescence a raceme or panicle (sometimes very contracted and appearing spike-like but spikelets at least shortly pedicellate); tufted or rhizomatous, terrestrial grasses

Spikelets (15–)16.5–25 mm long; anthers 7–13 mm long, usually fully exserted at maturity and distinctly dehiscing; pollen fertile; ligules 1–3 mm long; upper glumes 3–6-veined, 13–22 mm long; seeds produced; leaf blades often forming an angle of >45 degrees to culm

Spikelets 14–17.5 mm long; anthers 5–7(–8.5) mm long, not or incompletely exserted at maturity, indehiscent; pollen sterile; ligules 1–1.5 mm long; upper glumes 3-veined; seeds not produced; leaf blades generally forming an angle <45 degrees to culm
Inflorescence widely spreading with lowest branches whorled
Inflorescence narrow, with lowest branches solitary or paired
Upper glume more or less equal to spikelet
Upper glume usually about half (but up to two-thirds) as long as spikelet
Tufted or stoloniferous grass of north and north-west; leaves not distichous, sheath shorter than internodes; spikelets membranous, dull
Rhizomatous grass of near-coastal (and occasionally inland) saline environments; leaves distichous, sheath mostly longer than internodes; spikelets firm, shining
Inflorescence interrupted throughout, the spikelet-bearing branches mostly 1–3 cm long, the rachis clearly visible between the branches; spikelets mostly c. 1.5 mm long
Inflorescence continuous throughout (except sometimes at very base), the spikelet-bearing branches mostly less than 1 cm long and completely obscuring the rachis; spikelets c. 2 mm long
Spikelets 2–2.5 mm long; lowest branches of inflorescence appressed to main axis; widespread weed of southern Victoria
Spikelets 1.6–2 mm long; lowest branches of inflorescence sometimes spreading slightly from main axis; dubiously recorded from Horsham only
